title: The next wave of billionaires is coming
text:
The founders of ASX-listed medical imaging firm Pro Medicus, doctor Sam Hupert and tech expert Anthony Hall, appear next in line with their shares now worth close to $900 million each and their total individual wealth close to $1 billion.

Afterpay co-founders Anthony Eisen and Nick Molnar, who stepped down as CEO on July 2, are also both edging closer to the three commas club, sitting on shares worth close to $550 million each.

That’s despite the pair selling $47.15 million worth of Afterpay shares during a capital raise in June.

Multiplying wealth

A host of existing Australian billionaires have also multiplied their wealth this year, led by Mr Forrest.

Shares in Fortescue Metals have more than doubled in value this year, with Mr Forrest’s investment now worth close to $9 billion. This puts his total wealth closer to $11 billion, which would catapult him from eighth place to fourth in the Rich List.

Fortescue Metals’ share price has climbed 100.72 per cent this year, closing at $8.33 on Wednesday.

The top 200 companies on the ASX have risen 20.5 per cent this year.

Harvey Norman chairman Gerry Harvey’s net worth has cracked the $2 billion mark, climbing from $1.9 billion to $2.36 billion since he appeared on this year’s Rich List.

Shares in Harvey Norman have climbed 38.92 per cent this year, closing at $4.39 on Wednesday.

Netwealth founder Michael Hein has also seen his wealth continue to grow this year beyond the billion club he joined last year.

Others including SEEK founder Andrew Bassat and retail entrepreneur Ruslan Kogan have also fared well, significantly increasing their wealth although they remain mere multi-millionaires.

Good year for investors

Fund manager Geoff Wilson – who himself ranked 242 on the Rich List – said it had been a good year for investors compared with property billionaires.

“Low interest rates have pushed equity valuations to record levels while restrictions on lending have negatively impacted property prices,” he told The Australian Financial Review.

Executive remuneration specialist at PwC, Emma Grogan, said not all executives had ridden the sharemarket highs, only those whose companies had outperformed their peers.

PwC’s recent report found that 82 per cent of companies still rely on relative total shareholder return to hit long-term share incentive targets for executive pay.

“A rising share market does mean the value of executives LTI instruments increases,” she said.

“But given the widespread use of relative TSR as a performance hurdle, an organisation still has to be performing above the median of the market for LTI to vest.”
description: A string of top entrepreneurs and executives are on the verge of breaking into Australia's exclusive billionaires' club after the ASX hit a record high on Tuesday.
